author: Harriet O’Brien
title: Westley Farm cottages, Chalford: review
text: Telegraph rating 8/10 Westley Farm’s 75 acres are sublimely beautiful and home to five cottages and a central farmhouse from which owners Julian and Hege Usborne welcome guests and introduce them to the considerable glories of the area. Donkeys and sheep graze the fields, doves coo from the surrounding woodland, deer and foxes are frequently seen. Hornstone is the largest cottage, sleeping six and offering the best outlook. Bigger groups could take two or more cottages – in total there is accommodation for 20. Location 9/10 Westley Farm cottages, Chalford Between Cirencester and Stroud, you turn off the busy A419 and find yourself in a magical valley. Should you care to explore further afield, Minchinhampton, three miles away, is a quintessential Cotswold town, while Cirencester (8 miles) and Stroud (14 miles) offer fantastic museums – of Roman Britain and local life, respectively. Style/character 8/10 This is the real deal of a rural haven: five comfy cottages with simple furnishings and a terrific pastoral setting. They are run as sustainably as possible (not that guests are expected to follow suit other than using the Ecover washing up liquid supplied), and they are wonderfully pretty without being done up to the nines. Hornstone has a large kitchen with old-fashioned dresser, basic oven and wooden dining table. Its sitting room is snug rather than markedly stylish. The bathroom and master bedroom, both on the ground floor, are understated, as are the two twin-bedded rooms upstairs. The outdoors is stunning ‒ the cottage offers stupendous views over fields and woodland. Facilities 7/10 There are log fires to light and board games to play on rainy days; kitchens are adequately supplied ‒ although laundry facilities are communal and there are no freezers or dishwashers; sitting rooms have television and DVD players, but otherwise tech and gadgets are few and far between. Westley Farm cottages, Chalford Stroke a donkey, throw balls for Bella the hospitable collie, gaze at newts in the pond. Each cottage has its own outdoor space, complete with barbecue. Hornstone’s is a wrap-around deck on which you can follow the sun most of the day. Free Wi-Fi. Value for money 8/10 Hornstone from £650 in low season; rising to £950 in high (short breaks are possible out of peak season). Other cottages from £370 rising to £460. Family friendly 9/10 This is an amazing environment for children, who have the run of the meadows and woods. On Wednesdays, woodland adventure sessions for over-fives take place here, operated by Fireside Forest School (£25 per child, booking in advance recommended). Dogs are welcome at Westley – as are visiting horses. Eating The Usbornes provide cake and organic milk to start you off, thereafter visit Woefuldane Organic in Minchinhampton for more milk and cheese. Westley Farm cottages, Chalford Harriet’s Jolly Nice airstream trailer and farm shop is a five-minute drive away on the A419 – you’ll also get ice cream, pastries and brilliant burgers here. For meals out, walk over the fields (about 20 minutes) to The Crown at Frampton Mansell. Access for guests with disabilities Doorways are too narrow for wheelchairs; guests with less limited mobility could stay in the ground-floor bedroom of Hornstone as the bathroom is on this level, too. Details Chalford, Stroud GL6 8HP 01285 760262 www.westleyfarm.co.uk; www.farmstay.co.uk Telegraphtravel Follow @telegraphtravel
